question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
The demand equation for a certain product is

\[\displaystyle{}q^2+p^{3/2}+2p=20\]

where q is the number of units per hour the manufacturer can sell at a
price of p dollars per unit.

If the price is raised slightly from \$4 dollars, will the revenue
increase or decrease (use the elasticity of demand to do this)?
sols:
Using the hint and the first part, we have that

$\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{4\cdot q'(4)}{q(4)} = \frac{4(-5/4)}{2} = \frac{-5}{2} < -1$

As the value is less than -1, we see that the revenue will decrease.
hints:
Recall that the formula for the price-elasticity of demand is

$\displaystyle \epsilon(p) = \frac{p\cdot q'(p)}{q(p)}$.

Remember to compare this value to -1 to determine if revenue will
increase or decrease.
